hedline.hl1: Italian Food Site on the Web Now Speaks American, Too

abstract.p: Kalustyan, one of Manhattan's most fragrant and exotic food markets specializing in ingredients for Middle Eastern and Indian cuisines for 56 years, has expanded; photo; high-quality Italian food products can be ordered on Web at www.esperya.com; Jan Boscarino is selling Mississippi-style cheesecake at her midtown Manhattan shop, Martha Frances Mississippi Cheesecakes; photo; green chilies from hatch, NM, are making annual visit to Kitchen in lower Manhattan, which will roast them to customers' liking; photo; sleek doggie bags being created by some of Manhattan restaurants chefs noted for customers wishing to take leftovers home noted; photo; Dean & DeLuca is selling classic stopper-pourer for bottles of oilve oil for $2 each; photo (M)

block.p: Europeans have been ordering high-quality food products from Italy on the Web at www.esperya.com for two years now. Last month, the site began filling orders from America, and it is already a fine source for hard-to-get items like muscat grape raisins from Sicily ($8 for 8.5 ounces), 15 cuts of Latini organic pasta ($4.25 to $4.75 for 1.1 pounds), salted capers from Pantelleria ($8 for 5 ounces), sour cherry vinegar from Trentino-Alto Adige ($22 for 8.45 ounces) and Gruyere-like bitto cheese from Lombardy ($28 a pound). American orders are shipped from a warehouse in Elmsford, N.Y., and a $10 shipping charge is added to orders of under $100. Lots more food items, as well as tableware, cookbooks and travel information, are to be added.
